candidates.name: Jasmine Crockett
candidates.summary: U.S. Representative from Dallas. Rose to national prominence on the House Oversight Committee. Known for sharp, viral exchanges with Republican colleagues. Considered the frontrunner.
candidates.background: U.S. Representative (TX-30) since 2023. Attorney and former state representative. Member of House Oversight Committee.

candidates.name: James Talarico
candidates.summary: State Representative from Round Rock (HD-50). Former teacher. Known for bipartisan education legislation. Giving up his House seat to run.
candidates.background: Texas State Representative since 2019. Former public school teacher and education nonprofit worker. Georgetown University graduate.
pros: Bipartisan track record in the Legislature
cons: Lower name recognition statewide than Crockett

candidates.name: Ahmad R. Hassan
candidates.summary: Perennial candidate and businessman who emigrated from Egypt. Has run for office multiple times across Texas and Minnesota with minimal electoral support.
candidates.background: Emigrated from Egypt in 1984. B.A. from Friends University (1989). Law degree from Presidents College School of Law (2001). Businessman, real estate and mortgage broker, owner of Alexandria Realty and Mortgage. Former professional soccer player, coach, referee, and team owner.
cons: Perennial candidate — ran for U.S. Senate in both Texas and Minnesota, Harris County Judge, and TX State Senate across multiple cycles

recommendation.reasoning: National profile, strong fundraising, and federal experience give her the best shot in the November general election. Talarico is a strong Austin-area alternative with bipartisan credentials if local connection matters more.
recommendation.strategicNotes: Democrats need their strongest general election candidate to compete in November. Electability matters in a statewide Texas race.
recommendation.caveats: If bipartisan governance and education are your top priorities, Talarico may be the better fit despite lower polling.

candidates.name: Gina Hinojosa
candidates.summary: State Representative from Austin. Giving up her House seat to run for Governor. Known for education policy and progressive advocacy in the Legislature.
candidates.background: Texas State Representative. Former Austin ISD school board trustee. Attorney. Austin-based.

candidates.name: Chris Bell
candidates.summary: Former U.S. Representative from Houston. Previously ran for Governor in 2006. Most experienced candidate in terms of federal office.
candidates.background: Former U.S. Representative (2003-2005). Houston City Council member. Attorney. Ran for Governor in 2006 (lost to Rick Perry).
cons: Out of office for two decades

candidates.name: Andrew White
candidates.summary: Businessman and son of former Governor Mark White. Ran for Governor in 2018, finished second in the Democratic primary.
candidates.background: Businessman. Son of former Texas Governor Mark White. Ran in the 2018 Democratic gubernatorial primary.

recommendation.reasoning: Austin-area state representative with legislative experience and education expertise. In a 9-candidate field, she has strong local support and progressive credentials.
recommendation.strategicNotes: 9 candidates — a runoff is very likely. The top two finishers will face off in a May runoff.
recommendation.caveats: If you prefer a more moderate candidate or value federal experience, Chris Bell is an alternative.

candidates.name: Vikki Goodwin
candidates.summary: State Representative from Austin (HD-47). Giving up her House seat to run. Real estate background with focus on housing affordability.
candidates.background: Texas State Representative. Former real estate agent. Austin-based.

candidates.name: Courtney Head
candidates.summary: Legal and compliance professional running her first campaign. Contracts & Privacy Manager for a software company. Mother of two.
candidates.background: B.A. in Philosophy with Political Science minor from University of Houston (2017). Associate degree in Paralegal Studies from San Antonio College (2014). Contracts & Privacy Manager for a Columbus, OH-based software company. Negotiates multi-million dollar agreements with government agencies and Fortune 500 firms. Born in Honolulu, Hawaii. First-time candidate.
cons: Only $330 cash on hand — lowest funded in race
No elected office or government experience
Based out of state for work

candidates.name: Marcos Isaias Velez
candidates.summary: Steelworkers union leader emerging as a dark horse candidate. Assistant Director of United Steelworkers District 13. Houston-based labor organizer with a focus on wages and affordability.
candidates.background: Assistant Director of United Steelworkers union District 13. Former oil and gas refinery area operator in Texas. Blue-collar worker turned labor leader who has fought for higher pay, better benefits, and safer conditions. Houston-based.
keyPositions: Raising wages and rebuilding the middle class
Fully funding public schools and raising teacher pay
pros: Strong labor endorsements including Texas AFL-CIO
Message focused on wages and affordability resonates
Donor support from state Democratic Party network

recommendation.reasoning: Austin-area state representative with housing and real estate expertise. Most recognizable name in the Democratic Lt. Governor field.
recommendation.strategicNotes: Vélez has emerged as a serious contender with strong labor backing (Texas AFL-CIO). If labor issues are your priority, he's worth a look.
recommendation.caveats: Vélez's union endorsements and affordability focus make him a viable alternative, especially for working-class voters.

candidates.name: Joe Jaworski
candidates.summary: Former Galveston mayor and attorney. Ran for AG in 2022. Grandson of Watergate special prosecutor Leon Jaworski.
candidates.background: Former Mayor of Galveston. Attorney. Grandson of Watergate special prosecutor Leon Jaworski. Ran for AG in the 2022 Democratic primary runoff (lost to Rochelle Garza).
pros: Previous AG campaign — knows the race
cons: Lost 2022 primary runoff to Rochelle Garza

candidates.name: Nathan Johnson
candidates.summary: State Senator from Dallas (District 16). Flipped a red seat in 2018. Most endorsed and best-funded candidate. Business litigator who has passed 135 bills including Medicaid expansion legislation.
candidates.background: Texas State Senator (District 16) since 2019 — first Democrat to win the North Dallas district in three decades. B.S. in Physics from University of Arizona. J.D. from University of Texas at Austin. Business litigator and mediator at Thompson Coburn LLP. Composed musical scores for Dragon Ball Z. Won reelection in 2022 (61.9%) and 2024 (unopposed). Passed 135 bills.
keyPositions: Stop MAGA federal overreach through AG litigation
endorsements: State Senators Royce West, Sarah Eckhardt, Boris Miles, Jose Menendez
pros: Proven winner in swing district — flipped red seat
cons: Business litigator, not a prosecutor — no criminal law experience
Will give up Senate seat, creating open race in District 16
Some may prefer outsider over sitting politician
candidates.fundraising: $650,000+ cash on hand — leads all candidates

candidates.name: Anthony "Tony" Box
candidates.summary: Dallas attorney with an extraordinary service resume: Army officer, FBI Special Agent, and federal prosecutor. First-time candidate who wants to depoliticize the AG office.
candidates.background: B.S. in Accounting from Morehouse College. M.P.A. from Harvard Kennedy School. J.D. from Washington University in St. Louis. LL.M. in Taxation from Washington University. CPA. U.S. Army officer — commanded tank platoons in 1st Infantry Division, earned Airborne designation, deployed to Iraq as JAG officer. FBI Special Agent for nearly a decade — SWAT team, drug trafficking, major fraud. Assistant U.S. Attorney handling tax evasion and violent crime. Investigator for Congressional Commission on Wartime Contracting (uncovered $30B in waste). Currently private practice litigator at Gray Reed in Dallas. Shot at age 16 while apprehending a purse thief.
keyPositions: Restore professionalism and accountability to AG office
Consumer protection and antitrust against big tech
endorsements: State Reps Gene Wu (House Dem Caucus Chair), Ann Johnson, Ron Reynolds
U.S. Reps Julie Johnson and Marc Veasey
pros: Deepest law enforcement resume (Army, FBI, federal prosecutor)
No political baggage — first-time candidate with service narrative
CPA + multiple law degrees — uniquely qualified on financial crimes

recommendation.reasoning: Leads in polling, fundraising, and endorsements. Has 4 major newspaper endorsements, $650K+ cash on hand, and a proven record of passing 135 bills. Flipped a red Senate district — demonstrating electability.
recommendation.strategicNotes: 40% of voters still undecided. Tony Box has the strongest law enforcement credentials (FBI, Army, prosecutor) and newspaper endorsements if you want someone who will depoliticize the office.
recommendation.caveats: Box is the most qualified by pure legal resume, but Johnson has the strongest path to winning. Jaworski has the most AG-specific campaign experience.

candidates.name: Sarah Eckhardt
candidates.summary: State Senator from Austin. Former Travis County Judge (top county executive). Deep fiscal and government management experience.
candidates.background: Texas State Senator. Former Travis County Judge (2015-2020). Former Travis County Commissioner. Attorney. Austin-based.
candidates.fundraising: Leading fundraiser in Democratic Comptroller primary

candidates.name: Savant Moore
candidates.summary: U.S. Army veteran and Houston ISD trustee with a background in trucking, software engineering, and ministry. Published author on personal finance.
candidates.background: Houston ISD Trustee (District II) since 2024. U.S. Army veteran (Airborne Ranger, ~7-10 years service). B.A. in History from Howard University (2016). Truck driver, software engineer, small business owner (trucking), nonprofit founder, and minister in Houston's Sunnyside neighborhood. Author of a personal finance book. Father of three. From northeast Houston.
keyPositions: Fiscal transparency with plain-language public dashboard
Restore HUB program for minority/women/veteran-owned businesses
Taxpayer protection with grace periods before penalties
pros: Unique combination of military service, business, and elected office
Published author on personal finance — demonstrates subject-matter knowledge
Strong personal narrative — working-class Houston, Army Ranger, minister
Passionate about education finance during voucher debates
cons: Limited fundraising and name recognition vs. Eckhardt
History degree — lacks formal finance/accounting credentials
School board is low-profile for a statewide race

candidates.name: Michael Lange
candidates.summary: Finance professional with 40 years of investment management experience. Son of immigrants. Previously ran for Texas Land Commissioner in 2022.
candidates.background: B.S. in Finance from University of Texas at Austin (1985). Advanced Management Program at INSEAD (France, 1999). 40 years in finance and investment management across Texas, London, and New York. Chair of a Texas State Democratic Committee. Harris County Precinct Chair. Grew up in Houston, son of immigrants. Ran for Texas Land Commissioner in 2022 (received 20.2% — did not advance past primary).
keyPositions: Full transparency with plain-language financial reports
Grow small business employment share from 44% to 60%
pros: Strongest formal finance credentials — 40 years professional experience, UT finance degree, INSEAD training
Previous statewide campaign — received nearly 200K votes in 2022
cons: No endorsements from major organizations or newspapers

recommendation.reasoning: Austin-based state senator with executive experience as Travis County Judge. Deep fiscal and government management background makes her the strongest candidate for Comptroller.
recommendation.strategicNotes: Lange has the strongest formal finance credentials (40 years) if that matters most. Moore brings a grassroots/military perspective.

candidates.name: Greg Casar
candidates.summary: First-term incumbent, former Austin City Council member and labor organizer. Progressive champion in a safe D+26 seat. Member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus.
candidates.background: U.S. Representative since 2023. Former Austin City Council member (District 4). Labor organizer. Member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus.
pros: Safe seat — can focus on policy
cons: Very progressive — some moderates feel unrepresented

candidates.name: Esther Amalia De Jesus Fleharty
candidates.summary: Epidemiologist turned tech worker. Ran HIV clinics, oversaw food pantries, and served on the Texas COVID-19 task force. Latina daughter of Mexican immigrants and mother of two.
candidates.background: Epidemiologist who ran HIV clinics and oversaw community food pantries. Served on the Texas COVID-19 task force reporting to the Governor's office. Transitioned to the technology sector. Latina, daughter of Mexican immigrants. Mother of two. Campaign focuses on AI governance, healthcare, and working families.
keyPositions: AI governance for child safety and worker protections
pros: Unique background bridging public health, epidemiology, and technology
COVID task force experience demonstrates crisis management
Authentic personal story as immigrant's daughter
cons: No reported FEC contributions — extremely limited fundraising

recommendation.reasoning: Popular first-term incumbent with strong constituent services in a safe Democratic seat. No compelling reason to unseat him.

candidates.name: Brigid Shea
candidates.summary: Incumbent Commissioner. Environmental advocate with focus on water quality, flooding, and transportation. Seeking re-election.
candidates.background: Travis County Commissioner since 2015. Environmental advocate. Former journalist.
cons: Some feel county needs fresh energy
2020 Tesla tax deal vote is a point of contention

candidates.name: Rick Astray-Caneda III
candidates.summary: Government consultant with a PhD in Public Affairs. 12+ years with firms like Deloitte and Accenture focused on government modernization. Active in HIV/AIDS advocacy.
candidates.background: PhD in Public Affairs, MPA, and BA in Political Science — all from Florida International University. Originally from Miami. 12+ years as a consultant with Deloitte, Accenture, Public Consulting Group, and Weaver on government modernization. Built large-scale contact centers serving 1M+ people. Managed a $19M county COVID resilience grant for small businesses. PhD research on social vulnerability and disaster mitigation policy. President of Friends of the David Powell Clinic (HIV services). Led cycling team raising $300K+ for Hill Country Ride for AIDS.
keyPositions: Health & human services — prevention-focused health initiatives
Affordable housing using new 2025 legislative tools
Governance innovation — proposes Travis County Quality of Life and Human Rights Commissions
Collaborative, design-thinking approach to county government
pros: Strongest academic credentials in the race (PhD, MPA)
Extensive consulting experience managing government programs at scale
Deep community involvement in public health advocacy
cons: Originally from Miami — may face outsider perception
Campaign website light on specific policy proposals

candidates.name: Amanda Marzullo
candidates.summary: Civil rights attorney with 16 years reforming Texas's legal system. Gates Cambridge Scholar. Policy Director at Austin Community Law Center. Serves on City of Austin water and sustainability commissions.
candidates.background: Master's in Criminology and J.D. from University of Pennsylvania (full-tuition scholarship). Law degree from Cambridge University (Gates Cambridge Scholar). Policy Director and Senior Counsel at Austin Community Law Center. Former Executive Director of Texas Defender Service — built bipartisan coalitions to stop executions. Founded her own legal and policy consultancy advising the Innocence Project and Vera Institute. Serves on City of Austin Water and Wastewater Commission and Joint Committee on Sustainability.
keyPositions: Corporate accountability — critical of Tesla tax deal, wants moratorium on corporate tax breaks
Public transit — push to dismiss Paxton's lawsuit tying up Project Connect
Criminal justice reform and restorative justice
pros: Strongest legal and policy credentials among challengers
Track record of legislative accomplishments (restored 700K+ driver's licenses, bail reform)
cons: Legal/policy background may be perceived as advocacy-oriented vs. administrative

candidates.name: Reese Ricci Armstrong
candidates.summary: High school student, democratic socialist, and community organizer. Founded Students United for fairer workdays and special education support. The youngest candidate in the race.
candidates.background: Current McCallum High School student (previously attended LASA). Chair of LASA Young Democratic Socialists of America chapter. Founded Students United, organizing for fairer workdays, special education support, and mental health resources. Organized with Hack Club to improve nonprofit worker conditions — transitioned workers from contractor to full employment, secured wage increases.
keyPositions: Build thousands of permanently affordable social housing units
Expand Central Health toward universal healthcare
Require labor peace agreements for all companies receiving county investment
Invest in transit, bike lanes, and sidewalks
endorsements: Austin Students for a Democratic Society
pros: Genuinely grassroots, youth-driven campaign with no corporate PAC money
Real organizing experience with concrete worker wins despite young age
cons: Current high school student — youngest and least experienced by far
Ambitious platform may exceed county commissioner authority
Green Party endorsement may raise questions about Democratic commitment
candidates.fundraising: Small-dollar only — no corporate PAC money

recommendation.reasoning: Experienced incumbent with deep knowledge of county operations. Environmental and infrastructure focus addresses key Austin-area concerns.
recommendation.strategicNotes: Four-way race — if no one gets 50%, expect a runoff. No Republican primary, so the Democratic winner takes the seat. Marzullo is the strongest challenger with detailed policy proposals and legal expertise.
recommendation.caveats: If the Tesla tax deal and corporate accountability matter most, Marzullo is the strongest challenger voice on those issues.

candidates.name: Susanna Ledesma-Woody
candidates.summary: Austin native and Del Valle community organizer running for the third time. Nearly won in 2022, losing by only 248 votes. Founded the Del Valle Community Coalition. Current Del Valle ISD board trustee.
candidates.background: Austin native from Del Valle. Wife and working mother of three. Career in project management. Founded the Del Valle Community Coalition in 2010 (nonprofit for food and healthcare access). Del Valle ISD Board of Trustees (District 7) since 2011, currently Vice President. Played critical role in advocating for Del Valle Health and Wellness Center. County partnered with her nonprofit on COVID relief and vaccine outreach. Ran for this seat in 2018 (lost badly) and 2022 (lost by only 248 votes).
keyPositions: Equitable infrastructure investment — roads, utilities, water access
Affordable housing and supporting working families
Expanding Central Health services in the precinct
endorsements: Austin City Council Members Natasha Harper-Madison and Vanessa Fuentes
pros: Deep community roots — 15 years organizing in the precinct
Founded nonprofit that tangibly delivered services

candidates.name: Ofelia Maldonado Zapata
candidates.summary: Longtime community organizer with 30+ years experience. Visually impaired, retired on disability. Former AISD board trustee. Led Austin Interfaith for decades. Former chief of staff for Precinct 4 Commissioner Marcos De Leon.
candidates.background: Grew up in public housing in southeast Austin. Visually impaired, retired on disability in 1995. 30+ years of community organizing. Served on Austin Interfaith board 30+ years. LULAC District 12 director. Former chief of staff (1991-1994) for Travis County Commissioner Marcos De Leon. Elected to AISD Board of Trustees (District 2) in 2020 with 60.5%. Community representative in Travis County Public Defender's Office. Texas Anti-Poverty Project organizer.
keyPositions: Water quality improvement in Austin Colony
Creating cabinet of diverse community advisors
pros: 30+ years of community organizing through Austin Interfaith
Prior experience working in Precinct 4 Commissioner's office
Won AISD board race convincingly at 60.5%
Anti-poverty and social justice focus matches precinct needs
cons: "No more tax increases" could limit needed infrastructure investment
Less name recognition in this race than Ledesma-Woody and Morales

candidates.name: George Morales III
candidates.summary: Former Travis County Precinct 4 Constable with 27 years of public service. Led the county's Mobile Vaccine Collaborative (380K+ vaccines). Austin City Council renamed Dove Springs Recreation Center in his honor. By far the most endorsed candidate.
candidates.background: Lifelong Austin resident from Dove Springs. Became a father at 16, worked as a garbage collector, then pursued law enforcement. Graduated Huston-Tillotson University summa cum laude. Certified Master Texas Peace Officer. Travis County Precinct 4 Constable (2016-2024). Led county Mobile Vaccine Collaborative — administered 380,000+ vaccines. Austin City Council renamed Dove Springs Recreation Center in his honor (2019). Distributes ~5,000 backpacks annually. Annual Thanksgiving meals for ~6,000 families. Three-time Presidential Community Service Award recipient.
keyPositions: Expanding healthcare and mental health access
Preventing family displacement through affordable housing
endorsements: U.S. Reps Greg Casar and Lloyd Doggett
State Reps Sheryl Cole and Vikki Goodwin
pros: By far the most endorsements — Congress members, labor unions, nearly every Democratic club
Extraordinary community service record with multiple presidential awards
Deep institutional knowledge from serving as constable
Compelling personal story (teen father to college graduate summa cum laude)
cons: Law enforcement background may not appeal to all progressive voters
Moving from constable to commissioner is a significant role shift
Has not faced competitive elections recently
candidates.fundraising: Strong endorsement infrastructure suggests solid fundraising

candidates.name: Gavino Fernandez, Jr.
candidates.summary: Longtime East Austin community activist. Retired from City of Austin and Travis County. Former chief of staff for Precinct 4 Commissioner Marcos De Leon (1991-1994). Johnston High School graduate.
candidates.background: Born and raised in Austin near Ortega Elementary and Zavala Elementary. AISD graduate of Johnston High School (1972). Attended Austin Community College. Retired from City of Austin and Travis County. Former chief of staff for Precinct 4 Commissioner Marcos De Leon (1991-1994). Involved with Austin Brown Berets and El Concilio. Active in LULAC Austin and East Austin Lions Club. Austin coordinator for National Voter Registration Day. Ran for Austin City Council District 3 in 2022 (received 5.1%).
keyPositions: Funding mental health and addiction services for uninsured and homeless
pros: Deep East Austin roots and longtime community activist
Direct experience in Precinct 4 Commissioner's office (1991-1994)
Genuine personal motivation for public service
cons: 5.1% in 2022 City Council race — weak electoral showing
"No more tax increases" could limit needed investment
Precinct 4 staff experience is from 30+ years ago
Least organized campaign of the four candidates

recommendation.reasoning: Most endorsed candidate in the race with support from Congress members, labor unions, nearly every Democratic club, and the Austin Chronicle. Extraordinary community service record — led 380K+ vaccine distribution, recreation center named in his honor. Compelling personal story from Dove Springs.
recommendation.strategicNotes: Open seat after Commissioner Gomez's 30-year tenure. Four-way race makes a runoff likely. Ledesma-Woody nearly won in 2022 and has strong grassroots support — she's the strongest alternative.
recommendation.caveats: If grassroots community organizing matters most, Ledesma-Woody has 15 years of on-the-ground work in the precinct and nearly won last time.

candidates.name: Kathie Tovo
candidates.summary: Former Austin City Council member (District 9) and former Mayor Pro Tem. Extensive local government experience. Well-known in Austin politics.
candidates.background: Former Austin City Council member. Former Mayor Pro Tem. Adjunct professor. Deep roots in Austin civic life.
pros: Most government experience in the field
cons: City council tenure was sometimes polarizing
Some see her as an insider

candidates.name: Sam Slade
candidates.summary: Native Austinite, actor/comedian, and 20-year Democratic grassroots organizer. Radio personality (KLBJ-FM, ESPN Austin). Received a Texas House resolution from Rep. Hinojosa honoring his precinct chair work.
candidates.background: Born and raised in Austin. Actor and comedian with credits on Apple TV ('Brothers'), 'Iron Claw' film, HBO, and The CW's 'Walker.' Trained at The Second City (Chicago). Radio personality at KLBJ-FM (Dudley and Bob Show), ESPN Austin, KMAC. 20+ years of Democratic organizing: precinct chair in Travis County, worked on both Obama campaigns. Austin High School graduate. Received Texas House resolution from Rep. Hinojosa.
keyPositions: Public education funding — comes from family of teachers
Restrict new data center development to conserve water and lower utility bills
Lower costs for gas, groceries, healthcare, housing
Pledges 10 constituent calls per week and monthly roundtable meetings
endorsements: Travis County Democratic Party (#1 choice for HD-49)
pros: Deep Austin roots and 20+ years grassroots Democratic experience
Specific policy proposals (data center water legislation)
cons: Not endorsed by Austin Chronicle or Texas AFL-CIO

candidates.name: Montserrat Garibay
candidates.summary: Former Austin ISD board trustee and education advocate. Strong labor and education organizing background. Co-endorsed by Austin Chronicle alongside Tovo.
candidates.background: Former Austin ISD board trustee. Education and labor advocate.

candidates.name: Kimmie Ellison
candidates.summary: 20-year nurse practitioner with a doctorate. Peace Corps volunteer (Ghana). Breast cancer survivor. Directs a nonprofit helping uninsured women with breast cancer. Former HUD and White House staffer.
candidates.background: 5th generation Texan from North Dallas, moved to Austin for college in the 1990s. B.A. in Government from UT Austin (2000). Worked at HUD and in the White House. Became an RN in 2006, M.S. in Nursing from UT Austin (2008). Served in Peace Corps in Ghana (2 years). ICU nurse in Chicago. Doctorate of Nursing Practice from Rush University (2015). 20-year nurse practitioner. Directs nonprofit assisting uninsured women with breast cancer. Breast cancer survivor (diagnosed 2020). Serves on anti-eviction nonprofit board.
keyPositions: Increased teacher pay and school funding
pros: Deeply credentialed in healthcare — 20 years with doctorate
Lived experience as breast cancer survivor
Diverse life experience: White House, HUD, Peace Corps, ICU nursing
Direct understanding of uninsured patients' needs
cons: Described as 'energy agnostic' supporting oil/gas — may be too moderate for this progressive district
No prior elected office or legislative experience

recommendation.reasoning: Most experienced candidate with deep Austin government experience as a former City Council member and Mayor Pro Tem. In an 8-candidate field, her name recognition and policy depth stand out.
recommendation.strategicNotes: 8 candidates — a runoff is almost certain. Austin Chronicle co-endorsed both Tovo and Garibay. Garibay has the Texas AFL-CIO endorsement and strong labor support.
recommendation.caveats: If education is your top priority, Montserrat Garibay's AISD board experience and AFL-CIO endorsement may be more relevant.

candidates.name: Donna Howard
candidates.summary: Long-serving incumbent. Registered nurse turned legislator. Known for healthcare and education advocacy in the Texas House.
candidates.background: Texas State Representative since 2006. Registered nurse. Serves on Appropriations and Public Education committees.

candidates.name: Allison Bush
candidates.summary: 25-year Texas educator — teacher, school counselor, nonprofit executive, and community advocate across Central Texas school districts. Former union member with progressive advocacy experience in conservative communities.
candidates.background: 25+ years as teacher, school counselor, nonprofit executive director, and community advocate in Central Texas ISDs. Associate degree in Communication and Visual Arts from Kilgore College. B.A. in Communication and Special Education from Stephen F. Austin State University. Former union member. Progressive advocacy experience in conservative communities.
keyPositions: Curriculum standards based on educator expertise, not partisan politics
Fight to reduce teacher paperwork and improve retention
Oppose book bans and attacks on DEI
Charter school oversight — equal academic standards and fiscal transparency
Protect accurate history and age-appropriate health education
pros: Most direct K-12 classroom and administrative experience (25 years in Texas ISDs)
Union background aligns with teacher advocacy
Experience advocating for progressive education in conservative communities
cons: Less prominent endorsement list than Bazan's elected official endorsements

candidates.name: Victor Sampson
candidates.summary: UT Austin associate professor of STEM Education with a PhD in Curriculum and Instruction. Former classroom science teacher. Deepest academic credentials of any candidate.
candidates.background: Associate Professor of STEM Education at UT Austin. Chief Innovation Officer for Argument-Driven Inquiry. B.S. in Biology from University of Washington (1997). M.Ed. from Seattle University (1999). Ph.D. in Curriculum and Instruction from Arizona State University (2007). Former classroom science teacher.
keyPositions: Curriculum based on educational research, not politics
Anti-virtual schooling — incompatible with child development
pros: Deepest academic and research credentials — PhD and UT Austin professor
Direct expertise in curriculum design, which is SBOE's core function
Former K-12 classroom teacher plus academic research
cons: Academic background may seem theoretical vs. Bush's 25 years in Texas ISDs
Limited visible endorsements or organizational support

candidates.name: Neto Longoria
candidates.summary: Current Austin ISD bilingual special education teacher and parent support specialist. Master's in Public Affairs from UT Austin's LBJ School (2025).
candidates.background: B.B.A. in Business Administration from UT Austin (2015). M.P.Aff. in Public Affairs from UT Austin LBJ School (2025). Current Austin ISD bilingual special education teacher and parent support specialist. Former political canvasser.
pros: Active classroom teacher — brings current, firsthand experience
Strong focus on bilingual and special education — underrepresented perspectives on SBOE
Public policy education (LBJ School) bridges classroom and policy
cons: No traditional campaign website — relies on social media
Narrower issue focus than other candidates

candidates.name: Stephanie Limon Bazan
candidates.summary: Nonprofit leader, former educator, and 5th generation Texan. Most endorsed candidate in the SBOE race with support from multiple elected officials. Mom of two, first-generation college graduate, Austin ISD product.
candidates.background: Mom of two (ages 7 and 10). 5th generation Texan. Austin ISD public school product. First-generation college graduate. B.A. in English from St. Edward's University (2002). M.A. in Creative Writing from University of Leeds, England (2005). Former teacher at St. Edward's. Career spanning education, healthcare, law, and nonprofit sectors. Worked with LifeWorks addressing youth homelessness and literacy.
keyPositions: Historically accurate curriculum — not revised for political or religious agendas
Stop Christian nationalist influence in curriculum
Educator-led standards focused on critical thinking
endorsements: Travis County Tax Assessor Celia Israel
Former Austin City Council Member Ann Kitchen
pros: By far the most endorsements including multiple elected officials
Strong personal connection to public education (AISD product, parent of two)
Broad professional background across education, nonprofit, healthcare
Clear, forceful messaging against privatization and Christian nationalism
cons: Less direct K-12 classroom experience than Bush (25 years) or Longoria
Teaching was at university level, not K-12
Creative writing/nonprofit background less tied to SBOE's curriculum-setting function

recommendation.reasoning: 25 years of direct K-12 experience in Texas ISDs and Austin Chronicle endorsement make her the strongest choice for a board that sets curriculum standards. Only 5 of 15 current SBOE members are career educators.
recommendation.strategicNotes: This down-ballot race has outsized impact — SBOE decisions affect millions of Texas students. Bazan has the most elected official endorsements; Sampson has the deepest academic credentials.
recommendation.caveats: If elected official endorsements matter most, Stephanie Bazan has the broadest political support. If academic rigor matters most, Victor Sampson brings a PhD in curriculum design.

propositions.title: Expand Medicaid
propositions.description: Texas should expand Medicaid to ensure access to affordable healthcare for all residents.
propositions.reasoning: Texas has the highest uninsured rate in the nation. Medicaid expansion would cover over a million Texans using available federal funding.

propositions.title: Humane immigration reform
propositions.description: Texas should adopt humane and dignified immigration policies and clear pathways to citizenship.
propositions.reasoning: Depends on your immigration priorities. Both humanitarian and practical arguments exist.

propositions.title: Reproductive rights
propositions.description: Texans should have the right to make their own healthcare decisions, including reproductive rights, with removal of insurance barriers to treatment.
propositions.reasoning: Core Democratic platform issue. Aligns with bodily autonomy and personal healthcare decision-making.

propositions.title: Housing affordability
propositions.description: The state should use funding and regulation to address the housing crisis in urban and rural communities.
propositions.reasoning: Housing costs are a top concern across Texas, especially in Austin.

propositions.title: Public school funding
propositions.description: Texas should equalize per-pupil spending to the national average. Texas currently ranks 42nd.
propositions.reasoning: Texas ranks near the bottom in per-pupil education spending despite a growing economy.

propositions.title: Online voter registration
propositions.description: Texas should implement secure online voter registration, already used by 42 other states.
propositions.reasoning: 42 other states already do this. Modernizes voter access without compromising security.

propositions.title: Environmental standards
propositions.description: Texas should enforce stricter environmental standards for air, water, and biodiversity.
propositions.reasoning: Austin and Texas face growing environmental challenges including air quality, water scarcity, and urban heat.

propositions.title: Cannabis legalization
propositions.description: Texas should legalize adult cannabis use and automatically expunge past cannabis-related convictions.
propositions.reasoning: Combines drug policy reform with criminal justice reform. Depends on your personal stance.

propositions.title: Raise state employee wages
propositions.description: State and school employee salaries should be raised to national averages with biennial cost-of-living adjustments.
propositions.reasoning: Texas state employees and teachers are paid below national averages, contributing to recruitment and retention challenges.

propositions.title: Redistricting reform
propositions.description: Texas should ban racially motivated and mid-decade redistricting.
propositions.reasoning: Fair maps are foundational to representative democracy. Texas has a long history of redistricting controversies.

propositions.title: Fair taxation
propositions.description: The federal tax burden should shift to the wealthiest individuals with working-class income tax relief.
propositions.reasoning: Depends on your views on federal tax policy and progressivity.

propositions.title: Expand public transit
propositions.description: Texas should expand accessible transit in rural and urban areas.
propositions.reasoning: Transportation is a top Austin concern. Expanded transit reduces congestion and improves access.

propositions.title: Red flag gun safety laws
propositions.description: Texas should enact Extreme Risk Protection Orders to prevent individuals with a history of domestic abuse from purchasing firearms.
propositions.reasoning: Gun policy is deeply personal. Balances public safety with Second Amendment concerns.
